div3.head: PROPOSITION 5.

p.hi: Plane numbers have to one another the ratio compounded of the ratios of their sides.

div3.p: Let A, B be plane numbers, and let the numbers C, D be the sides of A, and E, F of B; A has to B the ratio compounded of the ratios of the sides.

For, the ratios being given which C has to E and D to F, let the least numbers G, H, K that are continuously C : E, D : F be taken, so that, as C is to E, so is G to H, and, as D is to F, so is H to K. [VIII. 4]
And let D by multiplying E make L.
Now, since D by multiplying C has made A, and by multiplying E has made L, therefore, as C is to E, so is A to L. [VII. 17]
But, as C is to E, so is G to H; therefore also, as G is to H, so is A to L.
Again, since E by multiplying D has made L, and further by multiplying F has made B, therefore, as D is to F, so is L to B. [VII. 17]
But, as D is to F, so is H to K; therefore also, as H is to K, so is L to B.
But it was also proved that, as G is to H, so is A to L; therefore, ex aequali, as G is to K, so is A to B. [VII. 14]

But G has to K the ratio compounded of the ratios of the A also has to B the ratio compounded of the ratios of the sides. Q. E. D. 1, 5, 29, 31. compounded of the ratios of their sides. As in VI. 23, the Greek has the less exact phrase, compounded of their sides.
